Award.AwardTitle: New, GK-12: Growing the Green Collar Workforce for the 21st Century

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
TITLE: New GK-12: Growing the green collar workforce for the 21st century
INSTITUTION: Iowa State University

This project will support graduate student fellows who will act as the human interface to motivationally communicate to middle school teachers and students the excitement and innovations that are the scientific underpinnings of today?s technologically savvy, modern society. The rationale for this program is the need to solidly ground this country's educators and young students in STEM-theme pedagogy. In the long-term such research-based education and training is a prerequisite for facing the emerging societal challenge to generate technologies that will maintain a sustainable standard of living, which ultimately will be dependent on renewable sources of energy and industrial materials. This program builds on Iowa State University's established scholarly infrastructures that are designed to be interdisciplinary and address key technology gaps for harnessing renewable energy sources (solar energy) and generate carbon-based energy and chemicals using atmospheric CO2 as the ultimate carbon-source. This interdisciplinary research integrates core themes that are grounded in STEM research, which include the fields of plant sciences, agro-engineering, biocatalysis, biochemical pathway discovery and metabolic engineering, bioinformatics, biomaterials, chemical catalysis, and mathematics. Broader impacts of the project include increased professional development opportunities for middle school science teachers; expanded educational and career opportunities for K12 students in STEM disciplines, especially those from underrepresented minorities and economically disadvantaged; benefits to US economy resulting from well-trained, globally competitive workforce; and recruitment of female and underrepresented minority graduate students to associated academic programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Symbi GK-12 was the State of Iowa’s only NSF awarded GK-12 program.  The program was a partnership between Iowa State University (ISU) and the Des Moines Public School District (DMPS).  This school district is the largest in the state and serves a very diverse urban population.  Over 50% of the enrolled students are under-represented minorities and over 70% receive free or reduce lunch. Over 130 languages are spoken in this school district.

 

The two main objectives of the project were:

  1. Provide graduate students with the skill sets and communication proficiency to explain their science and illustrate core Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM)principles to a young and receptive audience.
  2. Provide middle and high school students exposure to inquiry-based learning experiences to enhance their overall interest in STEM disciplines.

Over the course of seven years (2010-2017) a total of 45 graduate students participated in the program. Twelve participated for two consecutive years. Six DMPS middle schools and one DMPS high school participated in the project with 57 science classrooms served. Fellows spent one full day each week throughout the school year collaborating with their partner teacher and interacting with the students. Each Fellow typically interacted with approximately 150 students during each school visit. 

The fellows brought a wealth of knowledge to the middle school and high school teachers - specifically introducing real world applications to the classroom curricula - here are some highlights:

  • Computer programming and Robotics
    • One Fellow worked with his teachers to engage and excite the entire Meredith middle school student body in computer programming. Students learned to code and were eventually able to have their robots complete challenging tasks such a pick up a soda can, turn around and set the can into a specific square marked on the floor a distance away.  
  • Forces in Motion and Aerodynamics
    • Students were introduced to a simulation game that demonstrated what computational modeling means for engineers by using real aerodynamic design tools used by engineers to develop aircraft. Actual flight performance data was collected during each flight and then used by the students to determine what the "optimal" design was for the aircraft.
  • Biorenewables
    • Students were introduced to sustainable and biorenewable technologies. The students grew and phenotyped corn mutations which lacked proper wax/lipid coverings, dissected kernels, identified everyday products that come from each of the different kernel parts, and participated in a small-scale biodiesel production lab. They were able to generate enough biodiesel to run the lawn mower on the school grounds.
  • Water quality
    • Students visited the nearby Gray’s Lake in Des Moines, to collect water samples to determine whether the lake was safe for swimming. The samples they collected were examined under a microscope for protozoa and tested for additional chemicals and polluting agents. Their data was uploaded to two international databases and compared to results from sites around the world.
  • Land use
    • Students assessed the Dakota Access Pipeline Project including the environmental impacts of oil development, potential negative consequences for water and soil quality, job creation, energy security etc. The students presented their findings to a state legislator who was a member of the regulatory board for the pipeline.
  • Many additional concepts were introduced to the students including the difference between qualitative and quantitative observations, concepts of engineering and the engineering design process, paleontology, and plant genetics.

Findings related to GK-12 Fellows

Findings show that the Fellows’ communication skills improved over the course of their participation in the program. The program also had a positive effect on Fellows’ contribution to their research labs, their ability to communicate research, scientific concepts, ability to mentor others, and K-12 outreach. Fellows’ abilities in these areas were also stronger than their peers. 

 

Findings related to K-12 students

Data collected from 5700 middle/high school students showed that there was a strong correlation in grades 7 and 8 between liking having a Fellow in the classroom and having more interest and confidence in STEM topics. The data also suggested a significant improvement in students’ attitudes toward science. Student STEM career interest and confidence data were collected from approximately 800 junior and senior students at Lincoln High School and Hoover High School (Des Moines, IA) during the 2014-2015 school year. Students who participated in the GK-12 program in grades 6-10 reported significantly higher levels of interest and confidence in STEM fields as juniors and seniors in high school, when compared with students who had not previously participated in the GK-12 program, and these differences were more pronounced for female students compared to male students. Students who participated in GK-12 in grades 6-10 also reportedly went on to take more STEM elective and AP courses in high school when compared to students who had not previously participated in the GK-12 program.
